title: Relating Service Level Agreements to records
content:
The service level targets for a Request, Incident, Change, Task, Problem, and custom record are based on Service Level Agreements as follows:

  • For Service Requests and HR Requests, generally, Service Level Targets are based on the agreement associated with the underlying offering. 
  • For Support Requests, Incidents, Changes, Tasks, Problems, and customized record types, generally, Service Level Targets are based on the Service associated with the record. If no specific agreement is defined for the service, the default agreement is used.
  • For Case Requests, Service Level Targets are based on the agreement associated with the underlying offering. If no specific agreement is defined for the underlying offering, the Service Level Targets are based on the service associated with the request. If no specific agreement is defined for the service, the default agreement is used.
The table below provides an overview of the available methods to relate a Service Level Agreement to a record:
Service Level Agreement Applicable SLA/OLA
The SLA/OLA field is set by one of the following methods
Service Agreement

The SLA/OLA field in the record.

Note: There is no default agreement for service requests.
  • Set the SLA/OLA field in the underlying offering.
  • Use a Set field business rule defined in the Service Request.
Support and Case Agreement

When a record is created, the system applies SLA/OLA with the following priorities:

  1. The SLA/OLA field of the record is applied if it is not empty.
  2. When item 1 above is not true, if the record and Support and Case Agreement have the same Service, and the Target Set for this record type is associated with this agreement, this agreement is applied.
  3. When neither item 1 nor 2 above is not true, if a default agreement is defined and the Target Set for this record type is associated with this agreement, the default agreement is applied.
  4. When none of the above is true, no SLA/OLA will be applied.
  • Use a Set field business rule defined in the Support Request.
  • For Support Request or Case Request,  set the SLA/OLA field in the underlying offering.
  • For Incident, Task, Problem, or Change, set a default value of the service specified on the Default values tab of the associated Incident/Task/Problem/Change model.
Human Resources Agreement
  1. The SLA/OLA field of the record is applied if it is not empty.
  2. When item 1 above is not true, the default SLA/OLA will be applied.
  3. When none of the above is true, no SLA/OLA will be applied.
  • Set the SLA/OLA field in the underlying offering.
  • Use a Set field business rule defined in the HR Request.

Note that different Service Level Agreement types (SLA and OLA) have different default agreements.

For all record types (requests, incidents, changes, tasks, and problems), it's also possible to define the agreement in one of the following ways:

  • For service, support, and HR requests:

    • Via a Set field business rule defined on the request record type which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Studio module. For more information on defining business rules, see How to add a business rule.
    • Via a Set field business rule defined on the underlying offering which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Rules tab in the offering. For more information, see Offering business rules.
    • Via the SLA or OLA/UC fields on the underlying offering. For more information, see Agreements.

  • For incidents:

    • Via a Set field business rule defined on the incident record type which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Studio module. For more information on defining business rules, see How to add a business rule.
    • Via a Set field business rule defined on the underlying incident model which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Rules tab in the incident model. For more information, see Incident model business rules.
  • For changes:
    • Via a Set field business rule defined on the change record type which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Studio module. For more information on defining business rules, see How to add a business rule.
    • Via a Set field business rule defined on the underlying change model which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Rules tab in the change model. For more information, see Change model business rules.
  • For tasks: Via a Set field business rule defined on the task record type which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Studio module. For more information on defining business rules, see How to add a business rule.

  • For problems: Via a Set field business rule defined on the problem record type which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Studio module. For more information on defining business rules, see How to add a business rule.

  • For the custom record types created in Studio: Via a Set field business rule defined on the customized record type which sets the SLA or OLA/UC field to the required agreement. You can define such a business rule from the Studio module. For more information on defining business rules, see How to add a business rule.

In addition:

  • The values of the Services, SLA, and OLA fields of Support Request/Incident/Change/Task/Problem are passed over to the corresponding task.
  • The value of the Services field of Service Request/HR Request is passed over to the corresponding task.
